Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Evolution of Systems Biology Underlying Fruiting Body Development in Fungi
Award.AbstractNarration:
Fungi are important pathogens of agricultural crops and humans, as well as beneficial root associates maintaining the health of our forests. Most fungi lack the ability to actively move. Instead, they grow vegetatively as hyphae, then spread from one location to another using spores that are carried by the wind. This project compares and contrasts the development of fruiting bodies of fungi that thrive in different environments, examining how fruiting body structure has adapted to a variety of environments. The project will identify genes that are responsible for adaptation of fungal fruiting bodies to different environments. The resulting understanding of fruiting body structure will yield basic science for novel control mechanisms that curtail the survival and dispersal of pathogenic spores. The proposed project will reach beyond the advancement of fundamental scientific research to benefit society by building on a successful outreach program that supports an environmental venture of fungal fruiting body cultivation at local urban high schools in New York City and Philadelphia. In addition, the project will bring fungal biology curricula to local students, addressing the Michigan state third grade standards, and to the MSU 4H Children's Garden.


Shifts in gene expression underlie the interaction of developmental processes that drive the differentiation of tissues and the evolution of new morphologies in multicellular organisms. However, studies of how emergent properties of these interactions lead to novel, complex phenotypes that elucidate the evolutionary processes of developmental mechanisms are challenging in complex organisms. Fungi in the Phylum Ascomycota, a group that includes numerous important plant and animal pathogens, provide model systems for these studies as they are easily manipulated, develop fruiting structures with a few well-characterized tissue types on common media, and have genomic resources that enable comparative and functional analyses. The proposed research will use comparative transcriptional profiling and functional characterization coupled with phenotypic analyses to reveal developmental mechanisms underlying several key morphologies of fungal fruiting bodies, and to reveal the evolutionary processes by which these morphological innovations arose and diverged across a set of fungi. The research will reveal the genetic basis of a greater scope of morphological features of functional importance, associated with niche adaptation, for fungal fruiting bodies in the expanded six genera, and identify the roles and interactions of transcription factors in the evolution of the fruiting body development in two model species, F. graminearum and N. crassa. As the first systems biological analysis of developmental divergence in fungi, this research will provide an insightful comparison to well-known examples of developmental systems in microbes, plants, and animals. By studying these diverse multicellular systems, we gain a better understanding of the constraints and potentialities that shape developmental biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PIs Townsend (Yale University) and Trail (Michigan State University) had been funded by the NSF (IOS-1457044, Collaborative Research: The evolution expression networks underlying fruiting body development and morphology in fungi, 01/01/2015–12/31/2019) with a goal to elucidate the evolution of the systems biology of fungal fruiting body development. Fungi exhibit a remarkable diversity of ecology and adaptive morphology, and sexual development plays a key role in the generation of that diversity. In this project, evolutionary approaches were used to identify genes that had shifted in gene expression during fungal growth and sexual reproduction of resistant spores, and that are critical for fungal adaptation and pathogen infection. Five species of four genera in the Sordariomycetes with significantly divergent ecology and morphology were investigated and compared. Phenotypes associated with many genes—including new transcription factors that function in sexual development—were identified and reported in eight articles in high impact journals as well as three peer-reviewed book chapters. This project provided an atlas of gene expression during the development of the sexual reproductive structure across five fungi and related species, and identified key gene networks regulating the morphological development and how they respond to environmental signals. 

 

II-a. Intellectual Merit

We have accomplished research goals set forth in IOS-1457044. Total data generated was greater than 3000 million sequence reads (250 Gb of data) that will have continued utility in future studies. We also generated an efficient analysis pipeline and developed a creative and powerful approach implementing ancestral gene expression to guide focused phenotyping on hundreds of knockouts (PLoS Genetics). This comprehensive analysis of our data revealed some key genetic characteristics underlying how fungi reproduce sexually, and for its novelty and insight, was recommended by a member of the Faculty of 1000. For the first time, we characterized the role of long noncoding RNA in regulation of sexual development in filamentous fungi (mBio). We identified the first fungal polyketide synthase gene essential for sexual development, and the Fusarium neocosmosphoriella genome released via this project  provide an important reference genome for studying the fungus’ transition to a soil saprotroph within pathogenetic lineages . We identified phenotypes of two major light sensors in N. crassa and published our findings recently (mBio and Molecular Ecology) providing models for how light-responsive pathways are involved in fungal sexual development. Our study revealing the transcriptomics, functional genomics, and phenotypic time course of sexual development (Eukaryotic Cell) was highlighted by the editor and publicly recommended by a member of the Faculty of 1000. The research incorporated network modeling of RNA-silencing genes in sexual development. Our recent review on advances in the field (Fungal Biology Reviews) provides background on the systems biology concept and experimental design, and describes the advances made possible in fungal developmental biology by these conceptual models. 

 

II-b. Broader Impacts.

This project supported two postdoctoral associates, a doctoral student and two visiting students, who received training in next-generation sequencing, transcriptomics, and functional genomic data analysis. Six undergraduate students have been trained in functional gene analysis and network modeling, and two of them co-authored our paper. One high-school student was trained in fungal genetics and performed gene function experiments, and will be a co-author on a paper in progress. Our outreach efforts also resulted in the development and implementation of a successful semester-long learning module at Common Ground High School in New Haven. We used pre- and post- experience questionnaires to assess student engagement in our environmental ventures outreach activities. We have developed labs for primary school to explore fungi and fungal-like organisms and their role in the ecosystem, developed a mushroom garden in the MSU children’s garden, providing educational content on why they are not plants or animals. 

 

Drs. Trail and Townsend are continuing to reveal diverse post-fertilization fungal sexual development phenotypes using increasingly genetically and phenotypically divergent fungi.
